{{autobiography|date=May 2014}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = International Anti-Poaching Foundation | logo = [[File:International Anti-Poaching Foundation Logo.png]] | type = [[non-Profit|Not-For-Profit]] (Australia), Registered Trust ([[Zimbabwe]]) | founded_date = 2009 | founder = [[Damien Mander]] | location = {{Plainlist| *[[Victoria Falls]], Zimbabwe *[[Melbourne]], Australia *[[Hoedspruit]], South Africa}} <!-- this parameter modifies "Headquarters" --> | origins = | key_people = {{Flatlist| *[[Damien Mander]] *Steven Dean *James Slade *Elliot Nobula}} | product = {{Plainlist| *Conservation Training & Operations. *Technological Advancement for Conservation. *Area Management. *Community – school place and global environmental education.}} | focus = Anti Poaching | Non-profit_slogan = "To protect and preserve wildlife in volatile regions" | homepage = [http://www.IAPF.org www.IAPF.org] | footnotes = }}
The '''International Anti-Poaching Foundation''' ('''IAPF''') is a [[not-for-profit|non-profit]] organisation registered in Australia, predominately operating on the African continent.<ref name=age>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/lifestyle/a-different-battle-20121125-2a25x.html|title=A different battle|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=ia>{{cite web|url=http://www.iapf.org|title=IAPF - International Anti-poaching Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> The group has a structured military-like approach to conservation, employing tactics and technology generally reserved for the modern-day battlefield.<ref>[http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/riseofthedronesjan2013.pdf Rise of the Drones – Africa Geographic] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124230/http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/riseofthedronesjan2013.pdf |date=2 April 2015 }}</ref>
==Background== Following service in [[Iraq]] spanning 12 years of duty, former Australian naval clearance diver and special operations sniper [[Damien Mander]]<ref name=age/> headed for Africa with the intention of using his niche skills for conservation.<ref>[http://beta.mnet.co.za/carteblanche/Article.aspx?Id=4613&Showid=1 Damien's Rhino – Carte Blanche] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130421223808/http://beta.mnet.co.za/carteblanche/Article.aspx?Id=4613&Showid=1 |date=21 April 2013 }}</ref><ref name="beat.com.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.beat.com.au/category/machine-tags/damien-mander|title=Damien Mander - Beat Magazine|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> What was initially to be a short adventure quickly turned into an obsession as Mander observed first-hand the harsh realities that front-line rangers and wildlife face on a daily basis.<ref>[http://www.mindfood.com/at-conservation-rambo-damien-mander.seo Conservation Rambo – Mindfood, Smart Thinking]</ref> Liquidating his life savings and real estate portfolio accumulated from nine years of military service, Mander founded the IAPF in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8095372|title=Damien’s War|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> He was soon joined by his working colleague, wartime veteran and friend of 11 years, Steven Dean. The pair now operate the IAPF in Africa, spending most of the year on the ground protecting wildlife.<ref name=ia/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africamediaonline.com/mmc/gallery/detail/events/anti-poaching-in-zim|title=Anti Poaching in Zim - Africa Media Online|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
Across much of Africa [[anti-poaching]] tactics have remained largely unchanged for decades.<ref name="blogs.abc.net.au">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.abc.net.au/nsw/2012/11/tales-from-the-anti-poaching-battlefield.html|title=Tales from the anti-poaching battlefield|date=29 November 2012|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> Small groups of undertrained and poorly equipped rangers are sent out for days on end to conduct patrols in remote and dangerous locations. Modern-day poachers have evolved and routinely utilise military tactics and equipment to kill individual members of high-target species, such as elephants, [[rhinos]] and [[gorilla]]s. Seeing this shortfall, the IAPF set out to fill the gap.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rhino-dialogues.co.za/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Use-of-Drones-in-elephant-poaching.pdf|title=Unmanned Drones in Conservation – Rhino Dialogs Website|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
What initially started out as a training organisation quickly expanded into a community outreach, management, and research-orientated outfit, capable of running autonomously or alongside existing projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ww2.blogtalkradio.com/urbanjunglesradio/2012/12/01/ujr-presents-damien-mander-of-iapf|title=UJR Presents: Damien Mander of IAPF|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="IAPF Website">{{cite web|url=http://www.iapf.org|title=IAPF - International Anti-poaching Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
==Recognition== The organisation has a strong emphasis on public relations, and the media has responded well to the story of two transformed soldiers now dedicated to conservation and to encouraging a modern generation to stand up and have more empathy for animals and the environment.<ref name="Jungle Warfare – 60 Minutes">{{cite web|url=http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8553858|title=Jungle Warfare|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> Mander is an outspoken animal activist who is not afraid to publicly voice his views on critical environmental issues, from poaching to increased human pressures on wilderness areas.<ref name="702.co.za">[http://www.702.co.za/onair/heardonair.asp?action=mainsearch The war against poachers – 702 Talk Radio South Africa]</ref> In 2013, three separate nominations at The [[Humane Society]] of the United States' 28th annual [[Genesis Awards]] featured stories on the IAPF.<ref>[http://www.humanesociety.org/about/events/genesis_awards/27th_nominees.html Nominees of the 2013 Genesis Awards]</ref> These awards honour animal welfare issues in the media.
In 2010, the TV program [[60 Minutes]] travelled to [[Victoria Falls]], [[Zimbabwe]] to film IAPF operations. This showcased to a large audience the plight of the black rhinoceros, listed as critically endangered and under increasing threat as the price of their horns continues to rise steeply in Asia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=8095372|title=Damien’s War|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> In 2012, 60 Minutes filmed the IAPF using unmanned drones (UAVs) in Mozambique's Niassa National Reserve.<ref name="Jungle Warfare – 60 Minutes"/>
''[[National Geographic Magazine]]'' shadowed the IAPF whilst writing its feature article "Rhino Wars." The article (which earned a first prize world press photo award for Brent Stirton<ref>[http://www.worldpressphoto.org/photo/2012-brent-stirton-nas1-hl?gallery=2634 Nature 1st prize stories – World Press Photo]</ref>) covered organised crime's role in poaching, the pros and cons if the rhino horn trade were legalised, and the militarised ranger training and operations that the IAPF delivers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/print/2012/03/rhino-wars/gwin-text|title=National Geographic Magazine - NGM.com|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
The IAPF is governed by a board of directors in Australia, a [[board of trustees]] in Zimbabwe, and an international advisory board.<ref name=ia/> It is independently audited annually. Registered as a [[not-for-profit|non-profit]](ABN 57142987782), the majority of its funding comes from the Australian general public.
The IAPF has attracted the attention and support of [[Monaco's]] Conservation Guardians, an organisation on whose board Mander sits as a Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.verybest.com/ezine/135/908/0/conservation-guardians--philanthropy-for-fauna-and-flora/|title=Conservation Guardians, Philanthropy for Flora And Fauna – VeryBest.com|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/hola3536donatellaknecht.pdf Donatella Knecht de Massy y su marido, Sebastien, en su mansión de Mónaco] ''Hello Magazine''</ref>
In May 2013, [[Damien Mander]] made a presentation about the plight of animals in today's society in a TEDx presentation held at the Sydney Opera House.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FCsyK4aRXQ|title=Modern Warrior: Damien Mander at TEDxSydney|first=|last=TEDx Talks|date=15 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Operations==
The IAPF has established two full-time operational centres. The first, combined with IAPF's headquarters, is based on the Stanley & Livingstone Private Game Reserve 13 km from [[Victoria Falls]] in Zimbabwe. On this Big Five game (lion, African elephant, Cape buffalo, leopard, rhinoceros) reserve<ref>[http://www.aarongekoski.com/pdf/85513200352176_menshealtharticle.pdf My year of living Dangerously – Men's Health Magazine]</ref> is a training academy where rangers from Zimbabwe receive basic and intermediate training.<ref name=ia/> The team also operates an anti-poaching unit, protecting the breeding program of black rhinos on the reserve.<ref>[http://www.timeslive.co.za/lifestyle/2011/10/02/wildlife-war-zone-hero Wildlife war zone hero – ''The Sunday Times'']</ref> Whilst no rhinos have been killed under the IAPF's watch, the nearest population at Sinamatella in [[Hwange National Park]] (100 km east) has tragically declined at the hands of poachers—from 74 down to just four rhinos in the space of a mere six years.<ref name="702.co.za"/> Despite the reserve sitting in a prime position for poaching (close to 4 international borders and surrounded by a population of 85,000 people – 60,000 of whom are unemployed<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/the-star/zimbabwe-battling-to-keep-rhino-poaching-in-check-1.1105721|title=Zimbabwe battling to keep rhino poaching in check - IOL|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>) it experiences very few breaches these days. The last poachers captured in the reserve were apprehended carrying automatic weapons and received a collective 60-year jail sentence.<ref name="blogs.abc.net.au"/>
The IAPF operation comes under close and constant scrutiny from the Zimbabwean authorities, who focus on the hardline tactics associated with their training and operations. Mander maintains that whilst there is a shoot-on-sight policy for armed poachers in [[Zimbabwe]], the IAPF's training focuses strongly on the correct escalation in the use of force. This ensures using the minimum amount of force required to get the job done.<ref name="contactairlandandsea.com">[http://www.contactairlandandsea.com/2009/Past_Editions/issue29/con29_africa.pdf Raw for Africa – Military skills applied in a new fight – Contact Magazine]</ref>
In South Africa the IAPF initiated the development of the Anti-Poaching Ranger qualification – the new national standard that aims to unify a fragmented industry.<ref name="IAPF Website"/><ref name="kruger2canyon.linmedia.co.za">{{cite web|url=http://kruger2canyon.linmedia.co.za/details/19-10-2012/training_is_the_best_weapon_against_poaching/15394|title=Details|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
Many benefits come from standardising the training of anti-poaching rangers, such as the potential for joint operations, allowing rotation, providing a career path, and developing a national certificate for rangers who have long deserved recognition.<ref name="kruger2canyon.linmedia.co.za"/>
The training materials making up the "Anti-Poaching Ranger Qualification" are scheduled for completion in late 2014. The organisations assisting the IAPF in compiling the manuals have co-ownership of the material. The project will make training and training materials more readily available, and at a much higher industry standard. This project fills a void in the conservation industry, and has been backed by individuals including [[Ian Player|Dr Ian Player]], who is largely credited with saving the Southern White Rhinoceros from extinction, and Pelham Jones, Chairman of the Private Rhino Owners Association.<ref name=ia/>
In the South African Tourism Update Magazine article titled "A Spotlight on Poaching", the IAPF's Anti-Poaching Ranger Qualification was listed as one of four noteworthy initiatives initiated to protect our wildlife.<ref>http://tourismupdate.co.za/Contents//Editions/Feb14/Conservation_Feat.html South African Tourism Update Magazine "A Spotlight on Poaching", retrieved 13 April 2014</ref>
==Ranger training==
When Mander was the Project Manager of the Iraq Special Training Academy in Baghdad and Dean was a senior instructor, they trained up to 700 paramilitary cadets at a time for redeployment. Using this experience, Mander and Dean set out to transform learning opportunities for rangers around the world by developing better education and training standards. The skills they learnt in [[Iraq]] were a start point for training in [[Zimbabwe]], and they set about providing it free of charge for rangers.<ref name="voanews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/iraq-war-veteran-battles-rhino-poachers-in-africa-138338229/159563.html|title=Iraq War Veteran Battles Rhino Poachers in Africa|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> This evolved towards developing national qualifications and a much more professional and structured approach in delivery.<ref name="kruger2canyon.linmedia.co.za"/>
The IAPF's rangers are taught such skills as ambush, patrolling, arrest, crime scene preservation,<ref name="voanews.com"/> and camouflage and concealment.<ref>[http://www.aarongekoski.com/pdf/36827862987088_africa geographic iapf.pdf On the front line – Africa Geographic Magazine]</ref> Many of the skills are an adaptation of military courses, adjusted to suit the environment in which they are required, and with a deep underlying conservation tone.<ref name="IAPF Website"/><ref name="contactairlandandsea.com"/> During training courses, even convicted poachers have been rehabilitated and sent out to work as rangers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.victoriafalls-guide.net/dehorning-rhino-by-the-international-antipoaching-foundation.html|title=De-Horning Rhino by the International Anti-Poaching Foundation|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
The illegal trafficking of wildlife is one of the largest criminal industries in the world alongside drugs, weapons, and human trafficking. As continued and increasing pressure is placed on wilderness areas, the IAPF endeavours to increase the level of defence it provides, evolving to stay ahead of its adversaries.
The organisation has grown from being a localised problem-solver to becoming a solution-provider. The lack of availability of unmanned drones and of superior training packages are two major shortfalls for most conservationists. These shortfalls have the full attention of the IAPF.<ref name=ia/>
==Volunteers==
The IAPF is assisted by volunteers both on the ground and abroad. Termed the "Green Army," this growing group assists with day-to-day responsibilities.<ref name=ia/> When deployed in Africa with the IAPF, volunteers come face to face with the African Big Five whilst also assisting with teaching, patrolling, and monitoring of wildlife.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thechronicle.com.au/news/dalby-man-works-save-rhinos-cameron-wheelehen/1205321/|title=Dalby man works to save rhinos|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
==Technology (UAVs)== [[File:Damien Mander UAV Launching.jpg|thumb|[[Damien Mander]] launching a [[UAV]]]] The IAPF's key members have accumulated significant amounts of time in modern wartime theatres such as [[Iraq]] and [[Afghanistan]], and have been exposed to evolving tactics and technology. Mander and Dean, having seen [[UAV]]s (Unmanned Aerial Vehicles or drones) technology deployed in Iraq, were convinced of its place in conservation. Whilst initial enquiries were made into attaining UAVs as early as 2009, the IAPF UAV program did not commence officially until 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/ex-soldier-takes-on-poachers-with-hi-tech-help-for-wildlife/story-e6frf7kx-1226541411880|title=Subscribe to the Herald Sun|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
Mander has remarked of the UAV program: "Having real-time intelligence greatly increases operational capabilities when reacting to poachers."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nouse.co.uk/2013/01/22/license-to-kill/|title=License to Kill|first=Bella|last=Foxwell|date=22 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> "A UAV can cover in a few hours what a ground team will cover in a week."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-12-01/iraq-veteran-brings-the-fight-to-poachers/4402626|title=Iraq veteran brings the fight to poachers|date=1 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> "Conservationists must now be given the capacity to embrace the same technology that is made available to the military."<ref>[http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/mander_on_3aw.mp3 Damien Mander talks to 3AW Radio – 3AW Radio]</ref>
In mid-2012, international media became aware of the IAPF's use of non-weaponized unmanned drones for conservation. Mander, along with IAPF's Technical Development Director Simon Beart (a former Royal Navy helicopter technician), started to regularly portray to the world the use of UAVs in conservation, and their thoughts on their future use.<ref name=rise>[http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/riseofthedronesjan2013.pdf Rise of the Drones – Africa Geographic Magazine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124230/http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/riseofthedronesjan2013.pdf |date=2 April 2015 }}</ref> Mander is quoted as asking, "Why could I have a UAV watching over me in Iraq, but these elephants here cannot have the same privilege?"<ref name=rise/>
Seeing articles appear in the media and hearing the call to arms, a number of Australians and South Africans came forward. A late-2012 Sydney UAV conference cemented a team of world-class standards.<ref name=ia/> The IAPF is moving towards the next phase of UAV operations, which consists of purchasing drones that are affordable, durable, and easy to operate from long range.<ref name=ia/>
Despite these plans, the IAPF is aware that many are pinning their hopes on the use of the unmanned drones as a "silver bullet" solution. Mander maintains a healthy degree of caution: "Drones are not the answer, they are a tool in the box. It is how we utilise these tools that will allow us to change the way we do things." An entire department within the IAPF has been developed to test and write the manuals for ground operations, utilising UAV technology.<ref name=ia/>
In addition to UAVs, the IAPF constantly explores new ways to modernise tactics and operations for anti-poaching.
==Rhino conservation==
The IAPF is often linked in the media and through its projects with rhino conservation. Mander has been quoted as saying, "The rhino is the hardest animal to protect. Poachers are willing to go to more lengths to kill a rhino than any other creature. If we aim to protect the rhino and succeed, we know that everything else in its ecosystem will be looked after."<ref name="blogs.abc.net.au"/>
Since 2008, rhino-poaching has increased significantly each year. A total of 633 rhinos were poached in South Africa alone in 2012. Rhinos are being hunted to extinction for their horns. As this animal, and thus its coveted body part, becomes increasingly rare, the market value increases, further aggravating the situation. Rhino horn has now become an ornamental object of status in Vietnam, where it has attained a street value of US$75,000 per kilogram.<ref name="beat.com.au"/> In other examples of Vietnam's desire for status-driven products, when the market has been saturated by these products, their price has dropped precipitously, resulting in plummeting demand. This strategy could work to reduce rhino poaching, given the current stockpiles of their horns (in South Africa there are 40 tons and in Zimbabwe five tons).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/opinion/damned-if-you-do-and-1.1330912|title=Damned if you do, and - IOL|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
Mander and Dean have journeyed to [[Vietnam]] in order to understand the illegal wildlife trade from the Asian perspective, so that they could make up their own minds as to whether a legalised trade in rhino horn could be a solution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nouse.co.uk/2013/01/22/license-to-kill/|title=License to Kill|first=Bella|last=Foxwell|date=22 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref> In an effort to understand the mindset of the consumer, Mander has made this observation: "I can't help but wonder whether, if my young son or daughter was dying, I myself wouldn't travel to the ends of the earth and beyond to try to save them, or at least give hope. When life is on the line, where do we stop?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/dailynews/opinion/hanoi-where-having-horn-is-status-related-1.1330861#.URdWarTrblI|title=Hanoi – where having horn is status related - IOL|publisher=|accessdate=19 August 2016}}</ref>
Mander's report on the journey, titled "Damned if you do and damned if you don't: legalizing the rhino horn trade," was widely published.<ref>[http://www.rhinoresourcecenter.com/pdf_files/134/1340580232.pdf Damned if you do & Damned if you don’t – Legalising the rhino horn trade – Rhino Resource Centre]</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Double jeopardy – Wildlife Ranching Magazine, South Africa</ref><ref>[http://www.iapf.org/images/documents/hola3536donatellaknecht.pdf Donatella Knecht de Massy y su marido, Sebastien, en su mansión de Mónaco – Hello Magazine]</ref> It attracted the attention of such luminaries as world-renowned rhino conservationist [[Ian Player|Dr. Ian Player]]: <blockquote>Damien Mander is an extraordinary man who was in the Special Forces in the Australian Army, and served in Iraq. He became interested in the rhino and came out to Zimbabwe where he has been working under the most difficult conditions. I think his report is outstanding, and certainly leaves no doubt in one's mind about the demand for rhino horn and the need for some clear thinking on the whole subject. My own view remains the same which is the position of the Wilderness Foundation and that there should be limited regulated trade in the horns that have been gathered through natural mortality.<ref name="ReferenceA"/></blockquote>
With the release of that article, the IAPF joined the debate between conservation groups calling for a review of the 1976 CITES ban, outlawing a trade in rhino horn. Mander's point of view is that Asians cannot be re-educated away from a 2,500-year-old philosophy of traditional medicine, and one would be arrogant to think so. The situation is worsening, and conservationists working on the ground in Africa need logical solutions. "At present, the only proposal on the table that make a rhino worth more alive than dead is a legal trade in rhino horn," Mander is quoted as saying.<ref>[http://www.702.co.za/onair/heardonair.asp?action=mainsearch The war against poachers – 702 Talk Radio, South Africa]</ref>
The situation continues to deteriorate. New solutions are needed. Many fear that the worst is still to come and trends certainly indicate this.<ref>[http://theweekendpost.com/2012/02/12/military-edge-to-anti-poaching-war/ Military edge to anti-poaching war] ''The Weekend Post''</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/nature/slaughter-of-rhinos-at-record-high-7687511.html Slaughter of rhinos at record high] ''The Independent''</ref>
==Chizarira National Park==
In 2010, the IAPF began negotiations with the [[Zimbabwe]] government to start work in [[Chizarira National Park]], the country's fourth largest (1,910 km2) and most ecologically diverse national park.<ref name=ia/> Approval to complete the feasibility study to resurrect the park was finally granted in 2011, and the study was completed in May 2012. The document outlines the enormous amount of work ahead—the result of over 20 years of neglect due to the financial hardships faced by the Parks and Wildlife Management Authority. Despite the neglect, Chizarira is described as an enchanting place, lost in time and still remaining as one of Southern Africa's most spectacular protected areas.<ref name=ia/> In anticipation of the project, Chizarira Lodge was donated to the IAPF to use as a headquarters, training facility and base for researchers.
==School education==
The IAPF's Schools Committee in Australia has made inroads at the grassroots level. The secondary school geography curriculum teaches Australian children about poaching and the Africa savannah, and uses the rhino as a metaphor for Mother Nature and for the struggle we are facing environmentally as a global community.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.IAPF.org International Anti-Poaching Foundation Official Website] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FCsyK4aRXQ Damien Mander TEDx Damien Mander at TedX]

revision.text:
The '''Inventory of Conflict and Environment''' (ICE) is a project initiated by Jim Lee, [[School of International Service]] (SIS) at [[American University]] in Washington, D.C.<ref>Inventory of Conflict and Environment (ICE), [http://www1.american.edu/TED/about.htm Mandala projects]</ref> He has also written extensively on environment and conflict, including the book "Hot and Cold Wars".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/459789656|title=Climate change and armed conflict : hot and cold wars|last=James R.|first=Lee|date=2009-01-01|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9780415778695|location=|pages=|oclc=459789656}}</ref> The ICE project makes use of case research and computer applications in international relations research.<ref>Franzel, Joshua ''et al.'' [http://www.innovation.cc/scholarly-style/franzel3lee.pdf "Inventory Building and Utilization with Information Technologies: The Use of Database and Pattern Matching Systems in Teaching and Research,"] ''The Innovation Journal: The Public Sector Innovation Journal,'' Vol. 11, No. 3, p. 2. 2005.</ref> The cases can be searched through a pattern matching tool.<ref>Franzel, p. 8.</ref> ICE establishes a perspective in which disaggregated data is combined with geographic information in the study of conflicts.
ICE Case studies are sets of categorical research projects meant to spur further research in specific areas of international dispute.<ref>ICE, [http://www1.american.edu/TED/ice/iceall.htm Case studies]</ref> The ICE cases are related to the [http://mandalaprojects.com/wordpress/ Trade and Environment Database project] (TED).<ref>Trade and Environment Database (TED), [http://www1.american.edu/TED/ted.htm project overview]</ref> Since 1991, the TED and ICE projects have produced over a range of case study projects. ICE has about 300 cases. Among the practical uses of such case studies, ICE provides information on environmental refugees, conflict dimensions, countries involved and related issues.<ref>Akashah, Mey. [http://www.environmentmagazine.org/Archives/Back%20Issues/May-June%202010/bytes-full.html "Bytes of Note: The Fight and Flight of Environmental Change,"] ''Environment: Science and Policy for Sustainable Development.'' May–June 2010.</ref> ICE case studies have been of interest in both research and policy arenas. The ICE cases can be found [http://mandalaprojects.com/wordpress/index.php/ice-cases/ HERE].
Conflict and environment are modern and age-old problems and the cases represent this continuum of impact. The history of conflict and environment dates back many thousands of years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/brief-history-of-climate-change-and-conflict|title=A Brief History of Climate Change and Conflict, Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|last=James|first=Lee|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> AT the root of these cases are control over resources and migrations of peoples. These two drivers will remain at the core of environmental conflict cases, now and in the future.
==ICE Cases and the ICE Search Engine== ICE project is an evolving search engine and a tool for looking at international conflicts in the context of events and in contexts of similar and/or different typologies. It is also a tool for scenario creation for analyzing new cases.<ref>School of International Service (SIS), [http://www.mandalaprojects.com/ice/ice-cases/ice_index.html ICE Search and Scenario Builder].</ref> Several researchers, students and universities have been part of the ICE project. It is the product of melding together approaches to the separate fields of environment and conflict studies.
The ICE system identifies the elements of conflict as aspects of a parsed scenario. Using ICE, an evaluation of any specific event or series of events facilitates consideration of an array of factors.<ref>SIS, [http://win14.american.edu/ice/search_ice.cfm#using How to Use and Interpret the Scores and Rankings]</ref> These factors include several types of information, including general, environmental, conflict, and decisions. These are represented by a series of indicators grouped into basket of categories. These factors are also searchable items on the search engine. {{col-begin}} {{col-3}}Environment Indicators # Continent # Region # Country # Habitat # Environ Problem # Scope {{col-3}}Conflict Indicators # Trigger # Type # Outcome # Conflict Level # Time Period # Duration {{col-3}} {{col-end}}
The "inferential" ICE search engine offers a pattern matching system and an additional weighting component for the researcher's evaluation and analysis. The [https://icedb.shinyapps.io/icedb/ Ice Search and Create Scenario Tool] is an upgraded version with more user options.<ref>Franzel, p. 4.</ref> The SST lets the user imagine new cases, input relevant attributes and see how it compares to other ICE cases. These scenarios come with a simple automated case analysis and can be saved or results downloaded.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Franzel, Joshua and James Lee. [http://www.innovation.cc/scholarly-style/franzel3lee.pdf "Inventory Building and Utilization with Information Technologies: The Use of Database and Pattern Matching Systems in Teaching and Research"], ''The Innovation Journal: The Public Sector Innovation Journal,'' Vol. 11, No. 3, pp. 1–8. 2005. * James R. Lee, [https://www.routledge.com/Climate-Change-and-Armed-Conflict-Hot-and-Cold-Wars/Lee/p/book/9780415592512 ''Climate Change and Armed Conflict: Hot and Cold Wars''], Routledge, 2009 * James R. Lee, [http://thebulletin.org/brief-history-climate-change-and-conflict "A Brief History of Climate Change and Conflict"], ''[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]]'', 14 August 2009
==External links== * [http://mandalaprojects.com/wordpress/ Inventory of Conflict and Environment website] * [http://www1.american.edu/ted/TED/index.html Trade & Environment Database] (TED) * [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP), [http://www.unep.org/conflictsanddisasters/Introduction/PostCrisisEnvironmentalAssessments/tabid/251/language/en-US/Default.aspx post-crisis assessment]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use South African English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = Isolezwe | image = [[File:Isolezwe (S.A).gif|250px|Isolezwe Logo]] | caption = | type = Daily newspaper | format = Tabloid | foundation = 2002 | ceased publication = | price = | owners = [[Sekunjalo Investments|Independent News and Media SA]] | political position = | publisher = | editor = | staff = | language = Zulu | readership = | headquarters = | ISSN = | website = {{url|//www.iol.co.za/isolezwe}} }} '''''Isolezwe''''' is a [[Zulu-language]] [[newspaper]] launched in 2002 by [[Independent News & Media]]. It is published daily in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]], in the [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] format. Editor Thulani Mbathi describes their target market as "the modernising Zulu ... [s]omeone who may go back home to the rural areas to slaughter a cow to amadlozi [the ancestors], but is as equally comfortable taking his family out for dinner and a movie in a shopping mall".{{citation|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2007-05-28-the-all-new-zulu|periodical=Mail and Guardian|date=2007-05-28|title=The all new Zulu|last=Tolsi|first=Niren|accessdate=2010-06-03}}{{cite web|title=Media Update (Isolezwe conquers the streets)|url=http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/?IDStory=18156|accessdate=24 June 2013}} ==History== In June 2004, ''Isolezwe'' launched their online edition; their fellow Independent News & Media publications described it as the first Zulu-language news website.{{citation|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=31&art_id=iol1087809565896Z400|periodical=Independent Online|title=Zulu goes online with Isolezwe website|date=2004-06-21|accessdate=2010-06-03}}{{citation|date=2004-06-30|periodical=The Mercury|url=http://www.themercury.co.za/index.php?fSectionId=283&fArticleId=2132750|last=Khan|first=Farook|title=Isolezwe launches into cyberspace|accessdate=2010-06-03}} In the five years after its founding, it performed much better than Independent's English-language South African dailies, growing from a circulation of under 30,000 to more than 95,000, according to [[Audit Bureau of Circulations (UK)|Audit Bureau of Circulations]] figures. Much of their circulation consists of single-copy sales rather than subscriptions. It continued its strong performance in the first quarter of 2010, with a 34% increase in circulation to 104,481, as compared to industry-wide 2.3% drop in sales. Circulation for their Sunday edition, ''[[Isolezwe ngeSonto]]'', also reached 71,219. Paper insiders disagreed on the reasons for the growth; editor-in-chief Mbathi credited [[human interest story|human-interest stories]] and local news, while joint managing director Brian Porter mentioned editorial content and sports as "vital ingredients".{{citation|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/business/article545837.ece/Zulu-papers-lead-SA-sales|title=Zulu papers lead SA sales|date=2010-07-12|accessdate=2010-08-26|periodical=Times Live}} ==Language== ''Isozwele'' is known for using a more urban form of Zulu, in contrast to its competitor ''Ilanga'', which describes itself as using a "purer form" of the language. ==Distribution areas== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; width:400px; height:150px;" |+Distribution{{cite web|title=Isolezwe Website|url=//www.iol.co.za/isolezwe|accessdate=19 June 2013}} | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''2008''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''2013''' |- ! scope="row"| Eastern Cape | | Y |- ! scope="row"| Free State | Y | Y |- ! scope="row"| Gauteng | Y | Y |- ! scope="row"| Kwa-Zulu Natal | Y | Y |- ! scope="row"| Limpopo | | |- ! scope="row"| Mpumalanga | Y | Y |- ! scope="row"| North West | Y | |- ! scope="row"| Northern Cape | | |- ! scope="row"| Western Cape | | |} ==Distribution figures== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; width:400px; height:150px;" |+Circulation[//www.abc.org.za/ Audit Bureau of Circulations (S.A)] | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"|'''Net Sales''' |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox Radio Station | name = LOS40 | image = Los 40.svg | area = Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Spain, Worldwide | branding = | slogan = ''Todos Los Éxitos'' (All The Hits)
''Music Inspires Life'' | airdate = 1966 | frequency = 93.9FM Madrid/Barcelona | share = | share as of = | share source = | format = [[Contemporary hit radio|CHR]] | language = Spanish | power = | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | owner = [[Grupo PRISA]] | website = [http://los40.com/ Los 40 Website] |city=|coordinates=}} '''Los 40''' ('''The 40''', stylized as '''LOS40''' and formerly ''Los 40 Principales'', {{lang-es|Los-cuarenta}}) is a [[Contemporary hit radio|Top 40]] musical radio network and radio station brand in many Spanish-speaking countries from [[PRISA#Music_and_radio|Prisa Radio]]. The station has its origins as a music show at Radio Madrid, today [[Cadena SER]] in 1966, where the 40 Principales chart was born, then evolved into a spin-off radio station in 1979. The brand’s network in Spain has 3,000,000 listeners alone. Some stations under this brand name are owned and operated or are licensed by [[Grupo PRISA]] to use the brand. Some LOS40 stations are operated by a local broadcasting company and affiliated with the company that holds a license to use the brand from Grupo PRISA. Each LOS40 network typically broadcasts its own national feed from its respective country. LOS40 stations broadcast in: *[[Argentina]] *[[Chile]] *[[Colombia]] *[[Costa Rica]] *[[Dominican Republic]] *[[Ecuador]] *[[Guatemala]] *[[Mexico]] (franchised to [[Televisa Radio]] and aired by many [[Grupo Radiorama|Radiorama]] stations) *[[Panama]] *[[Nicaragua]] *[[Paraguay]] *[[Puerto Rico]] *[[Spain]] Most LOS40 networks generally air Spanish and English contemporary hit music that mostly includes American, Latin American, Pan-European and British singers and bands. Most stations emphasize [[Latin Pop|Latin Top 40]] music; however Mexico, Panama and Dominican stations feature more European and English-language music whilst Chile and Costa Rica stations plays more [[reggaeton]] and [[Bachata (music)|bachata]]. It has a high-rotation playlist consisting mainly of tracks from its private chart. The main music genres that can be heard are pop, [[pop-rock]] and some [[dance music]] from the '90s, '00s and present day. == History == In 1965, the Ministry of Information and Tourism passed a law forcing medium wave radio stations to launch FM stations to develop FM in Spain. Due to the high costs of producing new shows, most of the schedule for the new stations was based on music, mainly classical music. In 1966, [[Cadena SER]] asked one of its broadcasters, Rafael Revert, to develop a new music show aimed at a younger audience. So he took the idea of the [[Top 40]] and created a chart with the 40 top singles of the week, which would be voted on by the audience. So, on July the 18th, 1966, the first show of '''''Los 40 Principales''''' was broadcast on [[Radio Madrid]], marking the debut of the chart list, with ''[[Monday Monday]]'' by [[the Mamas & the Papas]] as the first number 1 on the list. Soon, the show would be broadcast on ten [[Cadena SER]] radio stations. At first it was a daily show, revealing candidates during the week, and the new list each Saturday. The viewers would phone each station to vote for their favorite songs. The show was recorded in Madrid, then the tape was sent to all of the affiliate stations throughout Spain and broadcast simultaneously. The duration of the show was increased during the 70s from the original 1 hour to 2, 4 and finally 8 hours by the end of the 1970s. In 1979, Cadena SER decided to create new 40 Principales stations, which would be dedicated to the chart and its candidates 24 hours a day. At first, the 40 Principales stations were still part of Cadena SER, becoming an independent network in 1987, though still owned by [[Grupo PRISA]] alongside Cadena SER. In 1985, the 40 Principales main station began broadcasting live by satellite throughout Spain. In 1990, the chart show started being broadcast also on TV through [[Canal+ 1|Canal+]], and in 1998 also on the newly created 40 Principales TV satellite channel. The chart show got its present name, ''Del 40 al 1'' (''From 40 to 1''), in 1995. During the 2000s, 40 Principales was expanded through Latin American opening several stations in Spanish speaking countries with either local media companies operating stations within a country or listening area or Grupo Prisa operating a company within a country. In May 2016, Los 40 Principales re-branded as simply LOS40. The main reason was that the station "is so much more than a top 40 list"{{Cite news|url=http://corporatevision.io/corporate-vision-develops-strategic-roadmap-new-brand-vision-digital-transformation-for-global-music-radio-leader-los40/|title=Corporate Vision® develops new brand vision & digital transformation for global music radio leader LOS40|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en-US}}. In September 2017, the LOS40 TV channel was shut down after almost two decades of broadcasting. ==Controversy== In December 2014, DJ Paul Hip asked listeners of 40 Principales Chile what they would do for free music concert festival tickets.{{cite news |last=Barell|first=Ryan|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/12/22/rim-fm_n_6365022.html|title=Rimjob Live On Air Prompts Apology After Chilean Radio DJ Paul Hip's Competition Turns Weird|work= |location= |publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]''|date=22 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} The radio station hosted a competition for contestants to come up with their own challenges. If their challenge was accepted by the radio DJ, they were given the opportunity to complete it to win the tickets.{{cite news |last=Cullen|first=Clare|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/trending/outrage-as-woman-licks-whipped-cream-from-radio-presenters-bum-crack-live-on-air-to-win-concert-tickets-30859314.htmll|title=Outrage as woman licks whipped cream from radio presenters bum crack live on air to win concert tickets|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Irish Independent]]''|date=23 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} One female listener offered to do "actually anything, up to and including licking whipped cream out of a human anus" to win tickets to the Mysteryland EDM festival. Hip took the woman up on the proposal - in the middle of his show. On 17 December 2014,{{cite news |last= |first= |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/ryanhatesthis/outrage-after-a-radio-dj-had-a-woman-give-him-a-rim-job-live#.eqlyb0qVp|title=Outrage After A Woman Gave A Radio DJ A Rim Job Live On The Air|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BuzzFeed]]''|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} she completed the act live on air.{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.taringa.net/posts/noticias/18366249/Chilena-besa-trasero-de-locutor-de-radio-para-ganar-entradas.html|title=chilena besa trasero de locutor de radio para ganar entradas|work= |language=Spanish|location= |publisher=''[[Taringa!]]''|date=20 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}}{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://archivo.larepublica.pe/19-12-2014/youtube-chilena-besa-trasero-de-locutor-de-radio-para-ganar-entradas|title=YouTube: mujer besa trasero de locutor por ganar entradas para concierto y genera polémica - VIDEO|work= |language=Spanish|location= |publisher=''[[la Repubblica]]''|date=19 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} Hip then proceeded to invite listeners of the radio station to kiss the woman{{cite news |last=Payton|first=Matt|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/2014/12/21/radio-station-apologises-for-dj-getting-a-rimjob-live-on-air-4995304/|title=Radio station apologises for DJ having cream licked from his backside live on-air|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''|date=21 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} who had just licked whipped cream from his anus to win tickets of their own.{{cite news |last=Kinder|first=Tabatha|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/outrage-chilean-dj-receives-rim-job-listener-live-air-graphic-photo-1480391|title=Outrage as Chilean DJ receives 'rim job' from listener live on air|work= |location= |publisher=''[[International Business Times]]''|date=20 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} The radio station's production team [[Twitter|tweeted]] an uncensored image of the act, which went viral over Twitter and caused controversy, with Twitter followers calling the act "misogynist and humiliating" and questioning the station's ethics and journalistic ethic. The radio station later issued an apology saying they were sorry if they had offended their audience and they probably should not have accepted such challenge, but assured it was completely "voluntary and even suggested by the participant" in a contest that was open to what ever each contestant wanted to do. The radio station deleted the tweet promptly after the negative reactions and assured their fans the contest's only purpose was to have fun, and not to hurt or demean anyone.{{cite news |last=Roterman|first=Natalie|url=http://www.latintimes.com/womans-gruesome-challenge-get-free-concert-tickets-causes-outrage-chile-284383|title=Woman's Gruesome Challenge To Get Free Concert Tickets Causes Outrage In Chile!|work= |location= |publisher=''[[Latin Times]]''|date=21 December 2014|accessdate=11 August 2015}} ==See also== * [[40 TV]] * [[PRISA]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links== *[http://los40.com Los 40 Official Website] *[http://los40.com.ar Los 40 Argentina Official Website] *[http://los40.cl Los 40 Chile Official Website] *[http://los40.com.co Los 40 Colombia Official Website] *[http://los40.co.cr Los 40 Costa Rica Official Website] *[http://los40.do Los 40 Dominican Republic Official Website] *[http://www.los40.com.ec Los 40 Ecuador Official Website] *[http://www.los40.com.gt Los 40 Guatemala Official Website] *[http://los40.com.mx Los 40 Mexico Official Website] *[http://los40.com.pa Los 40 Panama Official Website] *[http://www.los40.com.py Los 40 Paraguay Official Website] {{coord missing|Spain}} {{Los Premios 40 Principales categories}} [[Category:International radio networks]] [[Category:Radio stations in Spain]] [[Category:PRISA]] {{DEFAULTSORT:LOS40}}

Ibrahim Rasheed | screenplay = Ibrahim Waheed | writer = Ibrahim Waheed | starring = [[Mohamed Jumayyil]]

[[Ali Azim]]
Nuzuhath Shuaib | cinematography = Moomin Fuad | editing = Ahmed Asim | music = Mohamed Fuad | studio = ES Entertainment | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2017|03|02}} | runtime = | country = Maldives | language = Dhivehi }} '''''Malikaa''''' is a 2017 Maldivian [[romantic drama film]] directed by Ali Musthafa. Produced by Malla Nasir and Ibrahim Rasheed under ES Entertainment, the film stars [[Mohamed Jumayyil]], [[Fathimath Azifa]], [[Ali Azim]] and Nuzuhath Shuaib in pivotal roles.{{cite news|url=https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/11594 |title=Malika Releasing on March 2 |language=Dhivehi |work=Mihaaru |last=Adhushan |first=Ahmed |date=13 January 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180326140615/https://mihaaru.com/entertainment/11594|archivedate=26 March 2018 |accessdate=26 March 2018 }} The film was released on 2 March 2017. == Cast == * [[Mohamed Jumayyil]] as Munaaz * [[Fathimath Azifa]] as Jeeza * [[Ali Azim]] as Hassan * Mariyam Shakeela as Salma * Ahmed Shakir as Hussen * Neena Saleem as Badhoora * Ismail Zahir as Naseem * Ahmed Asim as Ismail * Sujeetha Abdulla as Fairooza == Release and reception == The film was released on 2 March 2017. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:2017 films]] [[Category:Maldivian films]] [[Category:2010s romantic drama films]] {{Maldives-film-stub}}

'''National Cinematheque of Ukraine''' ({{lang-ua|Національна кінематека України (НКУ)}}) is the Ukrainian film studio that was transformed out of the well known [[Kievnauchfilm]] after the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]].
The animated film division was split off under the name '''Ukranimafilm'''.
==Selected films== ===Animation=== * Три Паньки на ярмарку (1991) * Енеїда (1991) * Як козаки у хокей грали (1995)
===Popular science / documentaries=== * Невідома Україна / Unknown Ukraine (1993)
==External links== * [http://www.cinema.kiev.ua National Cinemateque of Ukraine website]{{en icon}}, {{uk icon}}, {{ru icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081231143648/http://www.ukranimafilm.com.ua/history.html Site of Ukranimafilm]
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Cinematheque Of Ukraine}} [[Category:Cinema of Ukraine]] [[Category:Animation studios]] [[Category:National Cinematheque of Ukraine]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=November 2015}}
'''Primer Group of Companies''' is a [[Philippines|Philippine]] company engaged in the [[retail company|retail sale]] and distribution of consumer brands and products. The company carries international brands mostly lifestyle products. The Primer Group also operates its own lifestyle boutique which includes Res/Toe/Run,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleid=61333 |title=Res-Toe-Run unveils new retailing concept in Cebu |last=Dagooc |first=Ehda M. |date=May 10, 2008 |work=The Freeman |accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref> The Travel Club, Ladybag, Flight001, Bratpack, GRND, General and R.O.X .In addition to the retail and distribution, The Primer Group recently opened its first retail and merchandising academy - APEX.
== History ==
The Primer Group was founded in the [[Philippines]] on 1985.<ref>{{cite news|title=Manila-based retailer eyes growth in Cebu|url=http://www.philstar.com/article.aspx?articleid=408179|accessdate=19 October 2011|newspaper=PhilSTAR.com|date=8 October 2008}}</ref> It was formerly called Primer International Corporation (PIC) as a trading company, importing seasonal merchandise. In 1992, the company Primer Group ventured into apparel licensing of Disney and Warner Bros. Later the same year, Uniglobe Travelware Co., Inc. (UTCI) was established, opening the Primer Group's first retail concept store specializing in luggage; The Travel Club. Five years later, the first Bratpack store was launched; a unique lifestyle concept store for the young, hip and bold generation of today.
The company's five primary values are Entrepreneurial Spirit, Passion for Success, Integrity, Teamwork, and Self-Discipline (E.P.I.T.S.).
The company continued to grow in the year 2000s. From a retail and distribution company in the Philippines, Primer Group expanded business to its neighboring regions in Asia.
To date, the company distributes to [[Hong Kong]], [[Indonesia]], [[Japan]], [[Malaysia]], [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]], [[Thailand]] with 100 free-standing concept stores and 600 consignment deals in the [[Association of South-East Asian Nations]] (ASEAN). The brands carried by the Primer Group include Consumer and Industrial products. The consumer brands carried by the Primer Group include DC, Quicksilver, Volcom, Roxy, Fitflop, Kickers, KruZin, Native,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=723257&publicationSubCategoryId=85 |title=Nativity in black (and blue and red and ...) |last=d'Bayan |first=Igan |date=September 3, 2011 |work=The Philippine Star |quote=Native shoes are exclusively distributed in the Philippines by the Primer Group of Companies. T |accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref> Olukai, Sanuk, [https://www.sledgers.com/pages/about-us Sledgers], Tretorn, Ace, Eagle Creek, Delsey, Design Go, Mendoza, Tumi, Victorinox, World Traveller, Boxfresh, Eastpack, Ellesse, Gaiam, Hedgren, High Sierra, Jansport, Kangol, Slenderstone, Timbuk2, Tough Jeansmith, Outdoor Gear, Coghlans, Columbia, Mountain Hardware, Nalgene, Nathan, Salomon, Salvas, Sea to Summit and The North Face. Industrial products include Aircon.Network Philippines, Inc. (A.N.P.I.), Brushstroke Creatives, Primer Printing Services, Inc. (P.P.S.I.), South AmerAsia Chemical Corporation (S.A.C.C.), Stellar Equipment and Machinery, Inc. (S.E.M.I.) and Union Inks and Graphics Philippines, Inc. (U.I.G.P.I.).
==References== <references />
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.primergrp.com}}

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-84 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1992-058A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1992-058A|title=Navstar 2A-06|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 22108 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block IIA]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|1816|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|9 September 1992, 08:57:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II]] 7925-9.5,}} D214 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_slot = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|19914|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20451|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.7 degrees | orbit_period = 717.98 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-84''', also known as '''GPS IIA-6''', '''GPS II-15''' and '''GPS SVN-27''', is an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which forms part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the sixth of nineteen [[GPS Block IIA|Block IIA]] GPS satellites to be launched. USA-84 was launched at 08:57:00 UTC on 9 September 1992, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D214, flying in the 7925-9.5 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-84 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2a.htm|title=GPS-2A (Navstar-2A)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 11 October 1992, USA-84 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|19914|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20451|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.98 minutes, and 54.7 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It had PRN 27, and operated in slot 4 of plane A of the GPS constellation.{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/project/navstar.htm|title=Navstar|publisher=[[Encyclopedia Astronautica]]|first=Mark|last=Wade|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite has a mass of {{convert|1816|kg}}. It had a design life of 7.5 years, but was in service for twenty years, until its retirement in October 2012. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1992}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1992]] [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
